I came back to Counter-Strike after getting banned from CS:GO, hoping that CS2 would be a fresh start without cheaters - turns out that was a bad joke. New account, terrible trust factor and the same old problems again.

Despite this, the core gameplay is still solid. The shooting is fun, the matches are intense, and when the game works as expected, it's still one of the best shooters on the market. I don't care about spending money on pixelated skins - I play to shoot, not flex - but that doesn't change the fact that CS2 has an incredibly strong and dedicated community.

It's truly impressive that such an old franchise is still alive and relevant. Games like Counter-Strike, Team Fortress 2, and Grand Theft Auto prove that a strong community can sustain a game for decades.

CS2 has major issues that Valve needs to fix, especially matchmaking and cheaters, but I still enjoy playing it and keep coming back.

In CS2 you can enjoy:

Rampant Cheating
Terrible matchmaking
If you are not in a 5 stack of friends you will absolutely get Toxic teammates
Poor Optimization (game runs bad even on good machines) 
Subtick is an absolute joke and makes the game feel terrible.
bad maps/ not enough maps/ Every map feels the same/ removal of community maps every 6 months or so
The game looks like plastic and is extremely bright 
Bad Spray patterns/bad bullet registration

The list goes on and on.......

Counter-Strike 2 brings great improvements with the Source 2 engine, better visuals, and smooth, classic CS gameplay. Gunplay is satisfying, maps feel familiar yet refreshed, and the game rewards skill and teamwork.

Unfortunately, the experience is often ruined by the large number of cheaters in matchmaking. This seriously hurts fair competition and can be very frustrating.

Overall, CS2 is a solid and enjoyable game with great potential, but it needs a much stronger anti-cheat system to truly shine.

Counter-Strike 2: The Game That Killed My Will to Exist

Counter-Strike 2 wants you to feel like a tactical genius, a sharpshooter extraordinaire, a master of bomb defusal. What it actually does is beat your soul into submission while simultaneously insulting your intelligence and sense of fun. This game isnâ€™t a shooterâ€”itâ€™s a grim, lifeless treadmill where every match feels like corporate emails set to gunfire.

The maps areâ€¦ maps. Grey, generic, and lifeless. You spawn, you run, you die. You respawn, you run, you die. Every bullet fired feels simultaneously pointless and personally offensive. Enemy players move like caffeinated ghosts who somehow know exactly where you are at all timesâ€”probably because they do. This is less a test of skill and more a brutal exercise in futility and self-loathing.

Weapons? They exist. Recoil? Sure. But everything feels the same: spray bullets, pray, die, repeat. And the matchmaking? A delightful buffet of â€œwelcome to losing 16-0 in a lobby where everyone is clearly on some kind of performance-enhancing algorithm.â€ The learning curve isnâ€™t funâ€”itâ€™s a mountain of despair built on your corpse.

By hour 5, you stop thinking about improving. By hour 10, you stop caring. By hour 15, you realize the game has stolen all your enthusiasm and left your brain a smoking crater. Itâ€™s lifeless, soul-crushing, and somehow manages to be both boring and stressful at the same timeâ€”a remarkable achievement.

Final Verdict:
Counter-Strike 2 isnâ€™t a game. Itâ€™s a public service announcement about why you should never care about rank, aim, or personal dignity. Fun? Dead. Motivation? Dead. Will to continue gaming? Vaporized.

For many new players, it may be difficult to start ARC Raiders at this stage, whether they are primarily interested in PvE or PvP. In practice, beginners can be repeatedly killed by experienced players roaming the starting area, losing whatever basic loot they have gained from early PvE encounters.

The game appears to offer limited early-game protection or onboarding space where new players can learn core mechanics and build a minimal gear baseline. As a result, new entrants are being forced into unfair PvP engagements against players with substantially more time in the game.

This is a known challenge in extraction-style and open PvPvE games, and other titles often address it through measures such as starter-zone protections, matchmaking bands, opt-in PvP, grace periods, or other guardrails. In ARC Raiders, the current setup can create a persistent imbalance: some experienced players enjoy preying on new players in early areas, new players churn, and the environment continues to favor established players, which in turn discourages new-player retention.

If you enjoy the struggle and challenge of trying to survive a very hostile, and sometimes toxic player environment, while trying to enjoy the beauty of the game - give it a shot.
If you are like me who think a game should provide ample opportunities to actually experience the game you payed good money for, stay away.

Great game, fun to be had. Really enjoy the prox chat and helping others. After 100 hours I wish I wanted to play more but the PvP experience has become much more prominent. Not finding as many raiders looking to work together or even use the prox chat, which for me was the main draw. The PvP itself is actually very diverse with the array of tools you get to trap other players or even outright gun them down with awesome weaponry. The reverse of that coin is creeping in silence or waiting to target unaware raiders is evidently the safest way to play. This, unfortunately, becomes the most profitable way to play which ultimately overshadows the excellent PvE content. Fighting Arc is at it's core, simple and fun. Even after learning weaknesses and patterns I felt that adding my own challenge by working to keep as many raiders alive and well looted made the matches refreshing. It became less about loot and more about laughs. Great map layouts [Buried City might be the best multiplayer map ever] and increased pressence on environmental conditions also help rotate you through new encounters. The focus of the PvE content becomes about goofing around or becoming more daring for the sake of your fellow raiders enjoyment. The focus of PvP content becomes all about isolating yourself or sticking with your party with little raider interaction. The difference between the two play styles is so polarizing that I don't really feel that playing without aggression is viable anymore.
Overall I loved the time I have put into it and the experiences that were generated from other raiders but no matter how hard I have tried, these last few days have been filled with raiders no longer interested in cooperation. The risk heavily outweighs the reward of being kind and I wish that wasn't so. One of those special games that has a magical charm and I hope more people can find a way to interact with that.

Have fun everyone else. I can't stand it anymore.

I love Arc raiders, its my cozy game now! "Cozy??? How is Arc Raiders Cozy?!?!" I hear you saying, scarred from 99 matches of pvp in a row, but Hear me out... 

A Non PvP-er's review

Going into this I did NOT expect it to hit so hard but this??? This?? this is a game! Game of the year? Game of the decade! 

I've been adulting for some time and not been fully enraptured into a game for quite some time, since games like skyrim, Left4Dead, and Black ops 2, a lot of stuff just feels like fillers these days, but holy moly does this game shake up the scene!

It takes me back to Early Gmod days, where Proximity chat + fun games  was a great time, for whatever reason games went silent. You really didn't see anything quite like this, team v team games usually let you talk to your team, and battle royale games let you talk to your friends, this game lets you talk to everyone. It really feels like a social experience first, before its a shooter. The game really feels cozy, I've seen girls come to this game from Animal Crossing of all games, and heres why:

The aggression based match making is the perfect solution, to satisfy many playstyles. Where my friends have said they had to drop this game because the PvP is too toxic its every match for them, and I have to look at them a little dumbfounded. As I've been able to just hop in, find easy-going gamers and have a good time =) It's such a wonderful time helping and working together. I love the vision of a robot army uprising, us VS them gameplay game with uneasy alliance. 

Sure sometimes you get exploded fifteen billion times by a guy using ten different trip mines and eating cheetos loudly, but that happens so rarely. A player could misfire shooting right past us, Where some of my friends spring up like a cat spooked by a cucumber, thinking maybe this person turned on us, I just think maybe the friendly misclicked.

I love going on Combat-Medic runs, where I go agile and try and heal / revive as many players as I can, and support team fights against big arcs, something about it feels like a new kind of fun. Being helpful as a treat, contributing to the total joy in the lobby as much as possible lol. Sometimes PvPers find their way into my lobbies (which is insane hahaha, my lobbies are usually 100% chill.) 

And a lot of the time, it works out =). The stories, decisions, moment-to-moment, and the general feel of this game all feel so riddled with stakes, and consequence, mixed in with a narrative that is bitingly real. I think it was about time for a game like this. One where sure you're free to do whatever, but the core concept? The core heart of this game?

That would be the teams of strangers helping out one another, gifting the newbie things, risking their biscuit to revive others, people they'll likely never see again, whole squads of randomly assembled troops taking down a common enemy and not ruining eachother's fun even though the incentives are there?! That creates such a chaotic and fulfilling experience, that can strengthen a friendship and even lead to new ones! That, in my opinion, is what Arc Raiders is about. Humanity's capacity to come together and rise up against a task that is greater than yourself! 

So with all that said, You can't do it alone raider! Happy raiding, and maybe bring a defib... Maybe... For any unfortunate Cozy gamer that gets caught in the crossfire.

I really tried to like this game. The core gameplay is fun: avoiding or destroying the ARC, looting, and extracting. However, there will always be players who abuse the matchmaking system.

The main appeal of an extraction shooter is the uncertainty: What will happen? Can I trust this person? You never really know. In this game, we have Aggression-Based Matchmaking, which works on paper, but human nature is unpredictable. There will always be players who find ways to exploit the system.

For weeks, I didnâ€™t have to worry about getting shot in the back. Now, in almost every match, someone betrays me, and I end up losing weeks of loot. Just like that, gone.

The game is marketed as a PvE experience with PvP elements, but almost every mechanic fails when PvP is involved, especially for solo players.

Want to grab a Queen Reactor? Just drop with nothing, use the free safe pocket, loot the first breakable part, and die. No effort, no risk.

Want to complete Trial Challenges? Pray you donâ€™t load into a lobby with sweaty tryhards. They will show no mercy if you attempt trials in the same match.

Itâ€™s a great concept with huge PvE potential, but all of it is wasted because of PvP.

This game is an absolute blast. Some of the most intense and sweaty multiplayer shootouts I've ever had while simultaneously being one of the coolest naturally social games I've played. The PvPvE gameplay is fresh and fun, and going topside to scrounge up materials while fighting for your life is a joy. Totally worth the price.

All that being said I have some major concerns with the state of the game and its future. I have full confidence in the devs to find a strong equilibrium with the mechanics of the game and continue to take new risks while continuously releasing updates, but I also can't remember a time I've been so torn between salivating to boot up a game while also completely dreading it.

Currently the community is divided between purely PvP and purely PvE in a game that offers clear ways to enjoy both. Just go to any tiktok, twitch clip or reddit thread and you'll see in every single comment section PvP players calling PvE players whiners and dilusional for not expecting to be shot in the back in a game that might as well be called "shot in the back simulator 2026" And conversly you'll see PvE players blaming the games toxcity and lobbing personal attacks at anyone who dares camp the extraction point in a game that totally encourages you to do that.

Thanks to these opposing camps, it creates an edge to every round where you don't know who's friend and who's foe which is really the game's secret sauce for infinite hours of fun/fear. While I personally enjoy both aspects of the game, the severely underwhelming endgame content (a hefty prestige system and I guess raid bosses?) and the rapid speed at which players obsessively consume it's content as quickly as possible, has lead to a growing majority of players chosing PvP as the only real end goal. Because for as inteligent as the enemies are, nothing beats the rush of getting into a life or death firefight with a real person. I do believe PvP has a place in the current landscape of the game, but unfortunately ARC Raiders is starting to lose the unique interactions that made it so speacial in favour of a pure extraction battle royale.

To prove my point, there has been some bizarre gamer psychology bent around the game's matchmaking. Large swaths of players have been trying to "cheat" the system to get back into "PvE friendly lobbies" which don't actually exist. They don't exist because for as much as people would like to believe if you're a "good gamer" you'll be specially selected to join a group of like minded "good gamers" who want to loot peacefully and dance around in a circle holding hands, HOWEVER there will always be players in EVERY lobby with GOOD and BAD intentions. The fact that players despise the PvP part of the game so much they'd rather spend their time fighting the matchmaking system than other players, illustrates its biggest problem. The game's systems have created a negative feedback loop either intentionally or unintentionally. 

As an example, "friendlies" try not to shoot first and die to PvP players who are ecstatic to smoke someone who gives away their position and hesitates before pulling the trigger. Which then leads to once friendly players tired of dying and losing all their shit, choosing to shoot first, completing a cycle of turning friendly players into PvP players, effectively decimating their own population and growing a bloodthirsty one.

So while I do enjoy hopping on and playing with friends in duos or trios, getting into intense fire fights and barely making it out with my well earned loot, playing the game solo has become an incredibly taxing and miserable experience. Where paranoia wins out over trying to cooperate with strangers, leading to those cool ermergent social experiences, quickly dying off.

I don't know what the solution is and I don't think Embark does either. Its the natural progression and growth of a game community happening right before our eyes, for better or worse. While the game is still very fun and totally worth a try, at this time, I can't find myself playing much more of it. The game has begun its rapid slide into the battle royale category. A genre that doesn't really entice me as much as it might other players. While I'm very much looking forward to more updates and shake ups, I'm also incredibly weary of a community that has started to turn a super unique multiplayer experience into a run of the mill PvP looter shooter.

The game is great! If you buy it to play solos or to play with friends you're most likely going to have a great time. 
However, after completing the Quests, waiting for expedition to depart. There's not much to do right now besides trials. In other extraction shooters like EFT or Delta Force, I'd have that want to pursue rare items or just kit out weapons to show off. 
I think the looting system isn't quite developed for people to play that way, instead its a constant looting for crafting rechargers and ammo, nothing else. Items don't sell for much so you'll scrap a lot, there's no current auction system to bring prices up or down. There's really just no feeling of "oh I want to go get that, or try getting this" besides blueprints, but honestly risking those weapons to take down the bigger ARCs isn't worth it at the moment, other than being able to say you took one down. 
At the end of the game I just find myself roaming around, trying to complete trials, but the rewards from those are mediocre. As much as I hate to say it, I feel like completing everything else has made me more aggressive towards other players, just to feel that sense of urgency because I have nothing left to do.
What needs to be made; Auction Place - allowing items to be "rare" and "valuable". Especially for those who won't fight the Queen/Matriarch. More rewards/Dailies/Weeklies, besides just CREDS and Trials. A increase of loot for events, bring the community together for gear that will be worth it if done together, rather than hunting other raiders because you know for sure they brought in good stuff. 
It's still early, and I am sure I was able to get through the quests rather quickly than most will but just be aware that at endgame you might find yourself in a similar feeling. I'm looking forward to what the Devs have in mind with the future of this game.

Arc Raiders is a competent third person shooter only bogged down by the genre in which it presents itself and the story.

In the game, you begin as a nomad wandering down a road waiting to be given a tutorial on basic shooter and looting mechanics. Afterwards, you find a home with an indeterminant group of people who wander around a partially sunken city at all hours. These people send you and other players in pneumatic bank tubes to five areas so as to kill each other and find parts for expresso machines. The world has been destroyed, likely by the cliche evil AI that plagues the imagination of many science fiction writers. There isn't much more to the story than that there may be humans and robots in space.

The gameplay consists of inventory management, point selection in three skill trees which offer minute enhancement to the player's character, and spawning onto five maps to collect materials to make the next spawn in easier. The movement in the game is about as good as Eldin Ring. The player does not get a yak to ride, but must sprint around a map and sometimes roll. The shooting mechanic consists of pointing at weak points on drones, some drones have yellow colored weak spots, and others have propellers to shoot off, and shooting a leaving player in the back at the end of the match after indicating oneself to be friendly. Weapons do use projectiles and must be aligned accordingly to strike distant targets.

 Speaking of weapons, the weapons offered are rather strange in that there are colored tiers of weapons, but the higher tier is not usually better. The most perplexing to me is that there are legendary weapons which are markedly inferior to an easier to acquire lower tier. Other than the three legendary weapons, weapons have the ability to be upgraded four times and to have added attachments as to increase their ability.

There are some quests, but they are somewhat tedious or silly. The story presents itself poorly, although the story isn't good. I've seen rude people in any game that is multiplayer and this game is no exception. However, if you conduct yourself courteously and utilize voice chat, you will be spared the virtual back shooting 99% of the time.

I've played much longer than I realized. I have had very memorable instances of meeting a stranger or two and taking on the two largest bosses in the game. I have stored up the most coveted items. I have been shot in the back by people I have revived or otherwise aided. My pvp experience has only ever been to defend myself or another at the extraction elevator or extraction train. Generally, I have had fun with the game, but there comes a point when the maps have been explored, the guns have all been collected, and there is nothing to do. This isn't unique to Arc Raiders, but the five maps and no end game content do detract from the game's value, in my opinion.

I will add that you may erase your character and begin again. This is a prestige mode which grants the new character a permanent five extra skill points if the player collected five million in currency and items previously, along with twelve extra home base inventory slots. I have also read that there will be multiple new maps added this year of 2026. There are even supposed to be new enemy types added.

I realize I may have typed too much for someone wanting to know if they should get the game. Suffice to say, this is a solid 8.4/10 third person shooter with a weak story and a gameplay incentive for bad people to be bad.

This game is alright ill write why below


why

As I've gotten older, I've struggled to stick with games for awhile. But occasionally a game comes along that grabs my attention, and Arc Raiders is one of them.

[h2] General Gameplay [/h2]
It's a super fun and addicting gameplay loop where you drop into a raid, loot what you can, kill some ARC enemies, maybe kill some other players, and then extract. Whatever you managed to extract with, you get to keep. You can take it into the next raid, or you can put it in your ever-growing stash for later.

If you're struggling with managing your stash, I'd say recycle cheap guns you don't need at the moment, especially the easy to craft ones. I was holding onto everything for awhile and it was taking up a ton of space. Same with other items that are easily craftable once you level up your workbenches. It's worth hanging onto things like Springs, Wires, Duct Tape, etc. that you can only find topside or buy in limited quantities from Celeste.

[h2] PVP [/h2]
I'm not sure if it's officially been stated by Embark, but aggression-based matchmaking does seem to be real to some extent. As I was learning the game and leveling up, I mainly was focused on getting loot and killing ARC for quests and to level up my workbench. Most other raiders were friendly and doing the same thing. I only got shot at a handful of times in the first 20 hours or so. Eventually I wanted to try out some PvP, so I started killing people I came across. This definitely put me into lobbies where everyone was shooting on sight.

This has held true for the most part in the 100 hours I've played so far. That's not to say if you're a passive player, someone won't decide to kill you and take your loot, but it's definitely not as sweaty as the hardcore PvP lobbies.

Generally though, people have been very friendly in this game. I've had people drop me blueprints and other items, and I've teamed up with people to take out some of the bigger ARC enemies. Only twice have I had someone say they were friendly, and then shoot me while I was looting. It sucks, but it has been very rare in the whole time I've been playing. Most PvP players will just shoot on sight in my experience.

[h2] Stability [/h2]
I have run into some stuttering mid-game (usually seems to be a connection thing, as I see the icons flashing on the right side of the screen), and a few times it's just totally frozen for a couple of seconds, but generally the game runs pretty smooth on my computer, and I haven't adjusted any settings. It's only crashed once for me in 100 hours.

[h2] Suggestions [/h2]

[h3] Saved Loadouts [/h3]
When you inevitably end up dying and losing your whole loadout, it can be a pain to craft everything you need again. The free loadout option is nice to quickly jump back in with the bare minimum, but there's no safe slot, which is a bummer if you come across something valuable. The ability to specify a loadout would be amazing. Ideally you could specify all of the guns and items you want, and if you have them in your stash, it would just pull them all into your inventory. If you're missing some of them, there could be an option to craft what you're missing if you have the materials -- or you could just let it pull in whatever you do have and go from there.

[h3] Not loading into games super late [/h3]
It feels pretty bad to load into a game at 18 minutes, run to the nearest POI, and find that every container has been looted. I've heard that this is supposed to then encourage you to kill other players who have already looted, but many times, those players have already extracted after 12 minutes. I've had several games where I run around to a few areas, find that everything is looted, and I can't even find another player. So I just extract with some basic materials. I get that they want to keep the lobby populated even when people extract early, but I wish the cutoff for when you can spawn in was a bit earlier. I've loaded in at like 25 minutes (I think?), and it wasn't QUITE as bad.

[h3] More stash size increases [/h3]
I maxed out my stash size pretty quickly, but I still spend a good amount of time figuring out what to sell or recycle, as I'm usually pretty full. I wish there was a way to increase it more. I've seen that Expedition gives you an increase, but I'm not entirely sure if it will be permanent. Even then it's a small increase, and you have to reset all of your Skills and lose all of your stash and learned BPs, which kind of sucks. Even if they upped the cost of the stash size increase by a lot, and gave us a few more increases, I'd be happy.

[h3] PvE Option for boss events [/h3]
This is sort of a polarizing topic, but I do think it could be nice to have the events like the Matriarch and the Queen have the option for PvE. These are FAR more fun to partake in when everyone is working together to take them down and helping each other out. Believe me, I love the PvP aspect of this game, but it feels really shitty to be working with 10+ people to take down the Matriarch, and then someone shoots you in the back. Obviously it's good to be aware and just stay in a big group, as people will generally help you out if there's a solo that's ratting and taking people out, but it definitely happens in the duo and trio lobbies more. Having people work together for the boss events feels way better in my opinion, but I know others will disagree.

I consider myself to be an absolute noob/casual when it comes to competitive games and PVP. I've tried an extraction shooter before and the realism really threw me off. It felt too gritty and aggressive.

Arc Raiders is not that kind of game. Compared to my previous experience in the genre and seeing friends play other games like Tarkov, Arc feels so much lighter and beginner-friendly. I've been playing this game for about a month now and I'm absolutely hooked!

Genuinely one of the best extraction shooters I have played in a while. The choice to make combat as minimal as possible, meaning no healthbars, floating names, minimap, was certainly a choice that paid off in their favor as it sells the immersion. For all of it's praise, there are definitely a few kinks that need to be worked on.

- No way of easily accessing quests mid-game
- Very limited stash space when first starting. It would be nice if it expanded when you unlock workshops, but barely (Like +3 extra stash space) then give you the option to pay.
- When crafting sometimes the quantity counter will just reset so when you think you crafted 5 bandages, you only made one because it reset.
- This one is more whining than genuine criticism, but the current FPS takeover from other studios has led people here who adopt a "kill-on-sight" protocol and it's frustrating when you need to, well, RAID in order to progress. Maybe if PvP XP was reduced and more PvE enemies were present this issue wouldn't be so present, but in it's current state its a gamble whether you'll get teammates who want to play the game or play CoD.

PvP rats and campers manipulate very simple matchmaking logic to get into friendly lobbies and kill on sight, receive ego boost and feast with easy loot. Other than that - beautiful 80's space art design, color palettes, one of the best audio design in multiplayer games, great scenes and variety of maps, superb graphics and physics, including AI.

Such a waste of hard work by game devs and designers.

This game is amazing, I've been having so much fun on it with some of my friends and especially running through all the quests with my main man. The maps are nice, the lotting and extraction aspect is fun, everything to do with upgrading everything at your room in Speranza. And to top it all off, fighting all the ARC is the best experience, there is a perfect amount of small ones sprinkled around the map and enough big ones that you have to watch where you're going unless you're prepared for a fight.
In saying all this, you probably knew I was gonna get to this point... the PvP has been nothing but a bad experience every single time. And that's not me carrying on and whining, that's just my truth. It sucks, it pulls me out of the experience and brings the vibe down 100% of the time. And the worst part is, majority of the time, you don't really get a chance to fight back, if someone that has no chill spots you they shoot and you're down in seconds with no hope of running away OR fighting back. Now, you might be thinking, why not just shoot first? That's not why I play the game, just because there is PvP in the game doesn't mean it's the main point. I know how it feels to die to other raiders and lose my stuff, I will never willing inflict that on people that wouldn't do it to me. But the people that are like that don't talk. They just shoot you. Kill you. And ruin your experience because they don't care.
The best part of this game is when people can come together to accomplish something that you couldn't do otherwise. I just fought AND killed a Queen with my friend, and before I could even loot a single thing I was shot, downed and knocked out by players who very clearly wouldn't be able to keep everything for themselves. That's gotta be the worst thing that's happened to me by far and it is so incredibly discouraging.
I don't wanna winge and not try and solve the problem though, so on the of chance this sparks some sort of uproar in the community or catches Embarks eye, I'll leave my ideas as well.

1. The obvious one is turn off PvP completely, but that would upset the people who enjoy it, and as much as I don't care for those people and their play style, they don't deserve to have it ruined for them.
2. Provide the option when loading into a match to toggle PvP, this way all the nice people who wanna do their own thing or even team up or interact with other friendly people are welcome to do so. And the ruthless players that are out for blood can simply do the same and keep to themselves. This way everyone gets what they want without spoiling it for other people.
3. The devs could put in more work than is probably worth it to pretty much overhall the armor system and provide different types that prevent more damage from players OR Arc, other similar stuff of that vein.
But option 2 seems like the common sense solution and a win win for all.

Seeing as this is a review however and not an angry email straight to the dev team I'll leave you with this.
Buy the game, I guarantee the good majority of your time playing SHOULD be enjoyable, whether it be from fighting arc, looting peacefully or mucking around with an entire lobby of friendly people for no reason (true story) you will have fun. Just please be wary and keep in mind that you ARE going to have games where you get completely dunked on by not so friendly players before you even know what's happening. Good luck and be careful.

Sooo. Its a good game, pretty quality... but im bored.
And you want to know why?

Arcs previous iteration before it became an extraction shooter was a PvE coop hero-shooter.
AND EVERYONE IS PLAYING IT LIKE THAT! And its the most fun part of Arc Raiders, shooting down robots with a randomly found team of people. I really wish the game catered to that a lot more.

Raiders could all have their own little agendas per raid. You dont know, but what if some of the raiders objectives is to sabotage the objective of another? So a PvE centric extraction shooter with the possibility of PvP. Enhance the number and difficulty of the Enemies, and you have jolly cooperation with PvP incentives.

Right now, the PvE jolly cooperation can be fun, but its a bit empty feeling.
Reviving a downed Raider at the nick of time after they took down a bastion, and then we both go to extract is all fun. But, nothing really pushes us to come togheter or go against eachother. The PvP AND PvE have no real goal, and so im kinda bored playing this game. Hoping that the RNG gives me the loot I want as I scavange a place for an upgrade.

Its like, Sea of Thieves but I cant explore the world at my own pace.

Now, the other thing that hit me as a downer is the bad excuse for using AI voices in this game. I can get behind making the voices say things in an increasingly developing game, where the VA shouldnt be bothered to voice for small pieces of dialogue. But this game uses them in cutscenes! I wouldnt be surprised if some of the script is written in AI, it sure feels like it.

GTA V is like a part of my childhood that never really went away. I remember coming home from school, booting up the game, and feeling like I was entering a different world. Los Santos wasnâ€™t just a mapâ€”it was a place where every street, every sunset, and every song on the radio sounded familiar. What makes GTA V so unique is that it was so alive. Just cruising around with no particular purpose in mind, listening to the radio, getting into random encounters, or just observing the world around you as it passed by left a memory that has stuck with me to this day. The characters, particularly Michael, Franklin, and Trevor, were larger than life. Even to this day, playing GTA V is like reliving that same experience of freedom and fun. Itâ€™s not just a game, but a memory of simpler times when time flew by without notice and every gaming session became a story to tell. GTA V will always be a special part of my gaming history as one of those games that shaped my childhood.

[h1] 13 YEARS OLD AND STILL RAMPANT WITH CHEATING??? [/h1]

Oh boy, I'm sure glad they added Anti-cheat to this game after a decade-long notorious cheating epidemic. I'm sure that means I won't run into any more cheaters in the new and improved "Enhanced Edition." I'm definitely sure I wont run into the same cheater over a dozen times over the course of several months. If I did, that means he could use his cheat menu to kill me. He could potentially lock me in a cage, dye my hair green, set me on fire, then launch hundreds of armored bank trucks going mach fuck at me. Hell, if that were the case, it could even be possible that I could run into dozens of cheaters of this caliber in every lobby I join. Fortunately, I don't have to worry about that due to Rockstar's fantastic anti-cheat. 

But, let's say, for the sake of the argument, this actually happened. I'm sure Rockstar would, in their diligence, quickly take care of the issue and ban this player. After all, that would be an extremely easy thing to catch, and in this purely hypothetical scenario I hypothetically reported this hypothetical player over a dozen times, more than enough for Rockstar to take action. Of course, after all, Rockstar cares about things other than selling in-game currency at an insanely marked up price. Rockstar has better things to do than intentionally code the game so that any time you try to make money in the extremely inflated economy of GTA Online, cars intentionally crash into you and total your product. They definitely didn't do this and allow it to occur for several years, then dial it back when people started to take notice and it became a massive internet meme. Rockstar isn't just some long-dead, money-hungry piece of shit company who would willingly let their prize game, the [i] second best selling video game of all time [/i], become such a notoriously toxic cheater-filled game that you can search "GTA Online cheat menu" and the first page has a detection-free cheat menu that only costs $5 and is so powerful you can literally force crash the game for every player in every lobby you ever join and block anybody from reporting you. There is no scenario where this game literally has a well-known FREE cheat menu. Of course not.

In short, I'm really glad they fixed this game. If they hadn't, one might think these developers are morally bankrupt scumbags who deserve nothing less than to be taken to trial at the Hague. Luckily, that isn't an issue. Thanks, Rockstar Games!

Stardew Valley changed my life in ways I honestly never expected.

I am a 38 year old divorced woman with 2 kids. My life wasnâ€™t crashing all at onceâ€”it was decaying slowly. My husband and I didnâ€™t have explosive fights. It was worse than that. We argued about nothing. Dishes left out. Money. That awful silence at dinner where no one wants to be the first to speak. They say communication is key but we had none of that.

One night, after another pointless argument about groceries, he went to sleep on the couch. I stayed up, scrolling. Thatâ€™s when I saw it.
Saw her.
Haley.
She looked so pretty. So feminine. So rude. I thought, Sure. Why not.

I named my farm after my biggest goal of the game; Haley

Thatâ€™s where it all went wrong.

I started waking up earlyâ€”not for work, not for my kidsâ€”but to water parsnips. I knew the villagersâ€™ schedules better than my own familyâ€™s. I remembered birthdays. I listened. I helped. I mattered. I. MATTERED.

No one yelled at me in Pelican Town. No one judged the way I used to water my seeds everyday before I knew sprinklers even existed.

My husband asked why I was smiling at my screen at two in the morning. I didnâ€™t answer. He wouldn't understand anyway. I was fishing. Willy needed me. My crops needed me. The community center needed me. Haley needed me.

Weeks went by.

My marriage didnâ€™t survive the winter, but my farm did. Even though I didn't have a greenhouse, I used that as a chance to get to know the game more. A break from farming, but more foraging, mining and fishing.

When the divorce papers arrived, I felt strangely empty. I had just unlocked the greenhouse. My kids asked why I seemed distant. I told them I was â€œworking on myself.â€ That wasnâ€™t a lie. I had hit level 10 farming.

Now I live alone. My house is quiet, but my barn is full. I have truffle oil money. I have a wife who lives in my computer and loves me no matter what. I have a cat and a dog that never judges me.

Do I miss my old life? Sometimes.
Do I regret it? No.

Because when I lie in bed at night, listening to the soft Stardew Valley music, I know one thing for sure:

Haley would never treat me like that.

10/10.
Would lose everything again.

A good game and an excellent introduction to CRPGs.

Some of the best parts have to be Act 2, the "Production Value" (Fully Voiced, nice character models), the engine (which allows you to do some pretty wild stuff, specially with shoving and throwing), official mod support for both PC and Console and the fact that it was created with cooperative in mind (good luck coordinating a 4 player game tho).People talk about replay value and, while it is there (especially considering a game is 40-hourish long), I believe it is lower than other games of the genre. Some people confuse details with replay value in my opinion. Having missed a couple of items or interactions is NOT enough motive for me to replay the game I'm sorry.

Alas, some of the worst parts are the level cap at level 12, using 5e (This is a personal matter of course, but I find 5e to be very lacking compared to other systems such as PF2e, one of the many warhammer 40k systems or even 3.5e), the companions backstory being mostly the same once you think about it, the fact that companions cannot wait to kiss me (I have a weird sexual tension scene with Gale 3 times per playthrough, leave me alone man...) and the story deflating quite a bit after act 3.


Overall, a solid 8/10 introduction to the genre with some problems here and there, but definitely worth the price and praise it received.

POE2 was my introduction into isometric, ARPGs and I couldn't have asked for a better first impression. So take what I say with that in mind.

So far I have about 90 or so hours in this game and from the beginning I felt pretty informed about everything I needed to succeed throughout the game. The deeper you go you'll start looking at the meta for builds and the specifics for your playstyle but isn't necessary as the progression through the game is solid and rewarding. There's plenty of flexibility between classes/skill sets and being able to build on those foundations keeps the game fresh and has you wanting to experiment. The mechanics paired with character weapons/skills/abilities is top notch, POE2 has spoiled me when playing other games in it's class. Art style is amazing, great enemy design that's topped off with being just graphically beautiful. Whether you're new to the genre or a vet, this game delivers for all and will keep up with you as far as you want to go. Absolutely recommend this game

Path of Exile 2 has incredible class and build diversity and nails the Diablo II style ARPG feel Iâ€™ve been wanting for years. There is so much to love here, which is exactly what makes this so frustrating.

The Trials gating ascendancies are not â€œhardcoreâ€ or â€œskill-based.â€ Theyâ€™re simply out of place. This isnâ€™t Dark Soulsâ€“style mastery. Instead itâ€™s a forced, roll-of-the-dice, aggravating chore that locks core character progression behind mechanics that clash with the rest of the game. Mandatory frustration is not the same thing as difficulty, and it feels like a disservice to the player experience.

Iâ€™ll keep playing because the foundation is excellent, but I canâ€™t wholeheartedly or honestly recommend this game until ascendancies are no longer locked behind Trials, or a real alternative exists.

I will probably change my review at a later time but right now i feel like venting.
Ive played poe1 for multiple thousands of hour and played through the campaign like a hundred times, there are some annoying parts but overall it is a pretty enjoyable experience. But this campaign, my god is it annoying. I dont feel like going into detail here and instead only talk about the one thing that annoys me the most. The bosses. There are so many bosses in the campaign and they are way too strong for campaign bosses. They are basically dark souls bosses and pretty much all of them constantly attack and constantly apply slowing and damaging ground effects. Meanwhile every time you attack, your characters slows down. I dont want to play dark souls.
I think with a lot of builds it isnt even possible to beat some of the bosses, unless you want to spend 50 attempts and get lucky, on a stupid campaign boss that doesnt even drop anything.
And if you cant kill it, then what? Youre basically softlocked, You could go back and farm some more, go buy gear or ask another player, but who wants to do that. In poe1 when you die at a boss you just respawn and the boss stays at the same health so you can bruce force your way through the story, which is how it should be. The actual game starts once your build is fully functional. 
Anyway, in poe2 when you die at a boss he resets back to full health. I know some people, especially dark souls players, get more motivated when they die to a boss but i dont think thats how most people feel. I think most people give a boss a couple of tries and then decide quit the game, telling themselves theyll try again tomorrow and then they never come back. Trying to turn poe into dark souls seems like one of those stupid ideas pushed by  executives that saw elden ring do really well and then mindlessly insisted the game should be more like that.   Ironically even though the game introduces a lot of new and unnecessary souls mechanics, the meta is the same as in the first game, kill everything so fast that it cant damage you. Wipe the entire screen of mobs instantly and oneshot all bosses.
Ok im done venting now and tomorrow i will go back to the boss that made me start venting.

I really want to love this game, I really do and I keep trying but I can't.

There is so much inherently wrong with this game and you can read of them above or below but there is a few I rarely see that I feel I must mention. 

We'll start with Aim,
There is a real obvious issue when shooting, micro adjustments and recoil feels horrible and thats all intentional, when controling and going along with recoil your input will be accelrated, where if you're going against it becomes a sluggish mess and this is ALL intentional, dice have admitted and don't want to change as "Some players might prefer it that way". Ever come around the corner and saw more than two people, you kill one and over flick or underflick the next guy and feel like your brain just lost the ability to handle recoil? This is the exact reason. 

Next is has to defenintly Snipers and DMRs,
How are they so bloody strong? Snipers feel so easy to use and impossible to avoid.
I've had more than a little to many 90 kill games with snipers, minus the one shot head shot DMR the mini scout is, snipers have a sweet spot mechanic that was only in BF1 and truly hated by the mass.. Why? Its infurating to deal with ESPECIALLY WHEN THERE ISN'T SURPRESSION OR FLINCH FOR SNIPERS. If you come up against a sniper, good luck if you don't have one of your own.
Dmrs fire fast they hit hard and are impossible to avoid even with speratic movement if the shooter can aim half decent.. Yet again they just don't have surpression or flinch, so why bother taking the fight with them long range and dying?

Last, cross platform. 
Why does it feel so messed up? 
I get aim assist and recoil reduction but the massive delay and the times I get killed 1 to 2 seconds later behind a wall to console is insane, after 3 of checking what killed me behind a corner and writing it down I've got it to about 10 to 1 console leading.
I just don't understand why PC can't turn cross platform off like Console can. 

The game can be funand it can be rewarding but more times than not it feels frustrating and unfair. 
I hope they fix a lot of the sluggish mechanics like the aim but I won't hold my breath.

I'll be honest in saying I had a lot of fun playing this game and often looked forward to it but there are some things that have made me want to uninstall going forward.

1. Crashes are frequent when you continue after one game of redsec. I often will crash after making it to round 4, which just takes away the fun for me. 

2. I personally don't find the open map game modes that fun, truthfully, I think the maps are too small. Even the largest maps feel like they do not offer enough variability. It really feels that if you just push hard enough with your team from objective to objective, that you win the match. I don't feel like there are true squad or team dynamics happening in my opinion.

3. Really, this feels too close to call of duty for my liking. If they added killstreaks, I wouldn't be able to tell much of a difference.

4. The story is not good, I love playing games for the story and intensity it shows but throughout it I just felt like I was not drawn into what was happening or why I was doing the things I was.

5. It's mindless fun without any of the charm. Sure I can shoot a sniper with a vehicle mounted lmg from over 100 meters away, but what if there are 5 snipers on the same hill? It's a losing battle.

6. I played more RedSec then anything else. You do not have to buy this game, and I wouldn't recommend it. Rodeo as a final 1 v 1 in RedSec is the worst.

Once again, despite having a clear blueprint for making one of the best FPS franchises in gaming, the developers have delivered a half-baked, uninspired product. The game feels stagnant, underdeveloped, and eerily reminiscent of Battlefield 2042. In trying to appeal to everyone, it ends up appealing to no one.

The identity crisis is obvious. The game attempts to cater to Call of Dutyâ€“style players with faster movement and pacing, yet CoD players donâ€™t want Battlefieldâ€”they already have CoD, and they quickly go back to it. Meanwhile, long-time Battlefield fans are alienated from the start. The slower, immersive experience of BF3, BF4, and BF1â€”defined by weighty gunplay, powerful sound design, large-scale immersion, and meaningful destructionâ€”is largely gone.

Instead of doubling down on what made Battlefield unique, the developers once again chose microtransactions and flashy skins that feel completely out of place. These cosmetics add nothing to the experience and only further erode the franchiseâ€™s identity. What truly set Battlefield apart from its competitorsâ€”Levolutionâ€”has been stripped down to the bare minimum. Watching a crane fall is dull compared to entire buildings collapsing in BF4. Minor environmental damage doesnâ€™t come close to the widespread, dynamic destruction seen throughout BF1, or the unforgettable cinematic moments like the zeppelin crashing mid-match.

Map design only amplifies the problem. Air vehicles are placed into maps so small and restrictive that a single dogfight can push you out of bounds nine times out of ten. The scale feels wrong, the flow feels broken, and the chaos that once defined Battlefield is missing.

From the moment the game reused the BF2042 engine, expectations were already low. While it may be an improvement over that disastrous release, it still falls far short of earning the Battlefield name. At best, itâ€™s a slightly more polished version of a failed directionâ€”proof that the franchise still hasnâ€™t learned from its mistakes.

Its honestly unreal how a game in late 2025 crashes like its their first time trying to roll out a multiplayer games netcode.  And no it is not on my end. I have the highest package of fiber wired directly into my pc with other consoles and devices in the house running at top speed no connectivity issues whatsoever. any other games Ive played on steam or other launchers are totally fine and its rare to have an issue in lobbies. This last weekend alone after maybe 16+ hours on BF6 I have been kicked no less than 20 times mid match. Unacceptable is putting it lightly when during the beta there were less issues. stop with the challenges and super long battle pass challenges(which I did buy btw) and fix your connections to what brings people to play the game.

I don't mind shelling out money to support any devs that care about their game as I have the expendable income and love to see them succeed. But why should anyone bother right now if its so blatantly obvious that their goal is to shove skins and "premium ultra special deluxe packages" on top of the battle pass add-ons when the base game doesn't even let you finish a match. Usually, I start my reviews with some sort of a backstory. Just because it's always interesting to know how did things happened the way they did, in my opinion. This time, though? There is nothing really interesting to tell. It's Todd Howard. End of the story. Todd was always a big fan of video games. One of the reasons why he wanted to join Bethesda. Todd used to love a game called SunDog: Frozen Legacy and always wanted to make such an epic space game himself. Bethesda wanted to explore a space theme too. They actually had that a game called The 10th Planet, which was ultimately canceled back in the '90s. So... yeah. Todd wanted something like that to happen, Bethesda wanted something like that to happen and, well, it happened. And since it's Todd we are talking about...

OK, OK, let's just admit it, we all knew it was going to be Skyrim in space. Everything Todd touches, he turns into Skyrim. Like I said, nothing really interesting to talk about. So, let's ask ourselves a question instead. What makes a good game? Personally, I believe it's two things. Said game should be interesting and addictive. You should always want to know what will happen next and the process of getting there should be as satisfying as possible. Ideally, those two things should co-exist, but honestly, even one of them is more than enough. Now, the problem with Starfield? The problem with Starfield is that it has neither.

First of all, I must say I really don't dig the â€œNASApunkâ€ design (and yes, they actually called it NASApunk). I mean, it sounds cool, but it looks... boring. The Elder Scrolls IV had those stylish gates and impressive armor and weapons. Skyrim had that thing about dragons. Here? it's just some metal and space. And I get it, they wanted things to look realistic. Nice idea, actually. They actually tried to make visiting a moon for the first time a big thing (they really wanted you to feel like you're getting there for real), there are ruins of the old Earth, etc. The problem isâ€”this game is anything but realistic. It was [i]planned[/i] to be realistic (more akin to Kingdom Come: Deliverance in a way, with tons of survival elements), but Todd thought something like that would be a â€œfun killerâ€ and, as usual, decided to stick with his formula for successâ€”to keep things as simple as possible. The result was a shockingly colorless game, in which most of the locations look exactly the same.

But OK, we can live with that. Unfortunately, the story is like that too. We are a random miner who found some boring-looking artifact and is now collecting more of those. The end. I mean, I do like it how the writing touches on lots of topics I am interested inâ€”the quantum physics, the religion, stuff like that. The problem isâ€”it does a terrible, terrible job with all that. Remember Star Trek: Discovery? A show, in which we had those giant tardigrades as a nod to the real-life creature of the same name that became the very first living being to become quantum entangled. We had a character named after mycologist Paul Stamets; we had that thing called the mycelial network... It was a brilliant thing. Lots of people disliked that show because it looks like they weren't ready for the a new way of thinking and just wanted more of the old-school â€œgreen men from outer space,â€ but still, it was rather brilliant fiction. Starfield? It just makes you chase artifacts and then tells you â€œa big truth,â€ which is extremely disappointing. And again, boring. So, the â€œinterestingâ€ part? Big fail. Now, what about the addictiveness? Well... about that.

See, Starfield is a pretty big game. It has lots of planets; you will be able to explore them (I like it how the map screen reminds me of SunDog), learn about their flora and fauna, you'll be able to build outposts (which are, like, an evolved version of settlements from Fallout 4), etc. Sounds cool. The problem isâ€”there is neither reason nor real motivation to do that. The problem with Starfield is that it offers you lots of things to do, but somehow fails to make you [i]want[/i] to do them. Just think about it. You just wasted hours scanning planets for life and resources. What is your reward? Well, you can make some money from it and get a rather unimpressive amount of experience. That's pretty much it. Sounds like a lot of fun, huh? I mean, remember, there are lots of planets. 1,692 to be precise. It's a game you, most likely, will never complete, at least not for real. Just because you will get bored. Yet they failed to come up with an interesting mechanics for exploration and just gave us... this. Sure, there is also crafting, but, surprise-surprise, it's boring too. To craft something, you need to do the corresponding research first and it will require a hell of a lot of gathering, so... yeah. â€œScrew that, I am not going to waste my time on thatâ€ is the most likely outcome here. Joy.

And yes, before you say anything, it's still the Creation Engine. Creation Engine 2, sure, and it's, like, the biggest upgrade ever (technically, Todd did not lie when he said that planets would revolve around each other, at least not completely), but the infamous clunkiness is still there. And so are loading screens. Lots and lots of loading screens... And it's a bigger problem than usual, since while in, say, Skyrim all we needed to do to visit a certain NPC was to, well, go and visit them, here we are supposed to go to our ship, to take off from the planet, set a course to the right planet (the UI is incredibly uncomfortable, BTW), and only then will we be able to find our guy. In other words, we have got lots and lots of extra actions and loading screens between A and B. It's just... annoying. And it won't get any better.

Does that mean there is nothing good here? Well, I did like some features. Like, in Starfield we can disable enemy ships and then board them to take control. In other words, we can steal enemy vessels. And it's not a bad thing to have, but hey. Let's admit it. It has been a thing since the '80s (Starflight, Sentinel Worlds I: Future Past, etc.). Cannot call something like that an advanced feature in 2023. Same goes for hiring your own crew. Especially thanks to how basic that feature is. And again, it's something you probably won't bother with.

And it's not like this game is perfectly made either. I mean, of course it's not. it's from Bethesda after all. Still, it's rather shocking to see that after eight years in development this game gives you trouble... changing the resolution. Personally, I didn't even find the way to properly switch to 4K through the menus. Manually editing the .ini file was the only thing that helped. With the game being good it would be an easy thing to forgive, but like I said, Starfield is anything but good.

Is it bad? Well... not really, no. If you 'll find yourself on an uninhabited island with only this game installed on your laptop? It would totally be possible to have some fun with it. I mean, it's a game. It feels a lot like Skyrim in space (yes, it even has powers), there are ships to fly, guns to shoot, quests to finish, factions to join, etc. It's not like there is something especially terrible about it or something. And it's not like it's a complete mess. There are bugs, sure, but those are not overwhelming. Not at the moment I am writing this, at least. The problem isâ€”at the moment I write this, there are more than 120,000 other games available on Steam. And lots and lots of those are [i]extremely[/i] good. Much better than Starfield. So, let me act like Mr. Spock and say that wasting your time (and as I said, Starfield wants, like, [i]all[/i] of your time) on this game? It sounds is illogical. There's literally nothing in this game that it does better than others. As sad as it's, Starfield is a boring routine, not an entertainment. Go pick up something else to play instead of it. Dixi.
she star on my field till i â„¢

I had expectations for this one. It failed to deliver
Personal combat is bad
Space combat, bad
item management terrible, counterintuitive, I am tired of spending soo much time on menus. I have to equip spacesuits everytime I go out? Why isnt that automatic? it is just dumb to need to suit up everytime I go out on a hazard planet.
The worst: it is a space exploration game, but you don't get to travel, no it is just some fancy (clumsy) menus where you point which planet to go and then you end in orbit and you can't land. No space jumps, no planet entry, hell, even when you are on planet side you can't even fly around with the ship to get near your objectives, you have to go on feet??? 
Everything is soo boringly difficult in this game it makes me tired. 
Not even a matter of lost money, I really wanted to like it.

It's not the loading screens or the half-assed story writing for me... it's the lack of content, incredibly repetitive quests that have you do almost the same thing in a location that's almost the same looking as the last, ship building that you can't build diagonally in, and base building that could have and should have been much more in depth. This game is the reason I've stopped preordering "premium" editions for games. 

Will update if the DLC revives this game.
HOWEVER! Buy this when on sale and for the Star Wars: Genesis mod conversion only!

The novelty of this game wears off fast.   The main story is boring, it has some interesting side quests, but not a whole lot.   Really lacking even now, three years on.  Expected better for a AAA title.

It's a bethesda open world rpg without the part that make a bethesda open world rpg work, which is the exploration. There is zero purpose to visit 90% of planets except to extract resources, which is mind numbing. The enemy outposts are mostly all copy pasted procedural generation, nothing more than glorified shooting galleries. Remember in fallout 4, how when you cleared a raider base, you could read terminals and holotapes to figure out what kind of gang you were fighting, and how they interacted with other factions in the area? Nothing like that in this game. I will say that the few missions that bring you to hand crafted areas are very good, the NASA mission and the terrormorph mission were fun, but everything else is just...dull. Even the special powers feel pointless, They might be OP, but I don't know because acquiring and upgrading them is the most tedious and annoying process in the game. Building ships is pretty cool, but most of the time they serve as loading screen transitioners. If this game was like 5 planets, with 3 of them being resource planets and 2 of them being hand crafted with detailed maps, that would be 100x better. Also this game has new game +, for some reason, it's also pointless, because barely any of the choices you make matter. The only reason for it is to upgrade your endgame ship and armor, which is also pointless because you can build and find better ships by the games halfway point and the endgame armor is not better than normal armor. Just a massive miss and the design philosophy makes me worried about future games from Bethesda.
I am not a singpleplayer-andie, but this was fun.
The ONLY REASON I paid for this game on steam because of the Star Wars Genesis Mod. Otherwise I would've kept playing the GamePass version XD
The more time goes on the more this game angers me as a Bethesda fan.
i love the game how ever it crashes alot

Alright game... menus are bad. Realllllly bad. Try managing 25 outposts with 100 things going inbetween them individually with no fucking menus to explain or remind where anything goes and why. Absolute bullshit. 200 hours into it and the managing system with outposts makes me want to fucking kms.

AVOID if you like bulding. Otherwise.... questing and besthesda standard stuff... same old crap... fallout remake basically in space. 
And i should mention the spaceship "battles" are absolute donkey shit.. Literally every space "section" is garbage. If you want a half decent space game, this is for sure not it. If you want a tedious, menail, repetetive (unrewarding and combatitivly easy) questing expierience you feel youve played before this is the game for you.  
Okay... one barely redeeming point. Exploration is kinda fun for a bit, but gets extremely repetitive. Once you have explored one vacant planet, you've see them all. But sometimes they have different colors. And a hole. Every planet has maybe one of six qualities (total of EVERYTHING) you have to discover across the galaxy. Same repetitive bullshit, different colors.
But wait, its not VATS... its TARGETING!

This games PG-13 writing, god awful menus, terrible space flight, boring locations and generic gunplay leave so much to be desired. I honestly don't even know if they can redeem it with the 2.0 launch, it's just so incredibly mid in every way.
requires EA app. characters are lame. gameplay has the potential to be fun but it's mid. having a hard time getting engaged in the game

Absolutely worth it if it's on sale, $20 allows me to feel ok about how often it crashes and Kay getting stuck randomly in a bush or against a wall. Story is fine, game looks beautiful but the dialog is what you'd expect from Ubisoft these days. Kay always sounds like it's her first time talking her way through a conversation and for a character like her in this storyline she is so unsure of herself and at times seems arrogant but for absolutely no reason, just makes it hard to like her. 

It's fun, it's Star Wars, it's AC Star Wars
Great game for 21$. Feels like you're in a Han Solo Star Wars movie.

A slow start and rough around the edges but I had a blast playing through this. Sneaking combat was fun and the game looks so good. Definitely the closest feeling I have had of being immersed in the world of star wars, even more so than the Jedi games.

Lowest settings possible and the game does nothing but still lag and crash. Completely ridiculous. It would be an amazing game if it weren't for the issues. Can't be a good game if you can't even play it.

Hi there MnkyBns. Iâ€™m sorry to hear that youâ€™re experiencing crashing and performance lag in Star Wars Outlaws. I understand this is not an ideal experience, and Iâ€™ve outlined a few troubleshooting steps below that should help address the issue.

- Installing Star Wars Outlaws on the same SSD as both Steam and Ubisoft Connect is the most [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help/article/000109505] optimised way [/url] to run the game
- [url=http://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/help/929135/how-to-perform-a-clean-boot-in-windows] Clean boot [/url] will rule out any background processes that could be conflicting (Overwolf, Steel Series, Corsair, iCue3, Razer, Synapse, etc.)
- Unplug non-essential peripherals (steering wheels and pedals, streaming equipment, additional monitors, VR equipment, etc.)
- Clear the [url=https://help.steampowered.com/en/faqs/view/6ad7-820d-8be5-e51f] Steam cache [/url] and [url=www.ubisoft.com/help?article=000061966] Ubisoft Connect cache [/url]
- Complete [url=www.ubisoft.com/help/article/000061047] all these steps in this FAQ [/url] as these can cross off more common causes for crashing
- Reinstall the [url=www.ubisoft.com/help/article/000062655] supporting software [/url] for the game
- [url=https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/topic/use-the-system-file-checker-tool-to-repair-missing-or-corrupted-system-files-79aa86cb-ca52-166a-92a3-966e85d4094e] Perform a SFC Scan [/url] if errors are detected, repeat the scan until all results are clear)
- [url=https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/windows/latest-supported-vc-redist?view=msvc-170] Clean reinstall the C++ supporting software [/url]

If these steps don't resolve the crashing issues for you, please [url=https://www.ubisoft.com/help?article=000075524] link your Discord and Ubisoft accounts [/url] and join the [url=https://discord.com/invite/ubisoftofficial] Ubisoft Support Discord server [/url] so that we can take a deeper look.

reviews.review: Might be the single worst game I have ever played in my life. And that is saying something.

I mean, neat game and all, its cool.  Also its 2026 and Ubisoft still can't optimize their games. Or is it just a Star Wars thing that makes them crash on PC? No, its the developers.  I have a 4080, way over the recommended GC, crashes are unacceptable, and I dont even have 3 hours clocked on this game yet.  Can I recommend this game? I mean, yes and no.  It's cool like I said, but I feel like if they keep making sales it will just enable this lack of TLC they are getting known for.  As a leading game developer Ubisoft should actually be leading by example, and releasing quality in both technical terms and creative terms, 50/50 isnt enough.  If you get it just keep in mind its going to be a neat and frustrating experience, and that Ubisoft should be ashamed for their lack of technical ability in 2026.

good original story, great graphics and visuals

the controls feel clumsy. You're running and stop for a jump over a crate?! Assassin's creed has fluid parcours at least.
The AI is suboptimal, I'm hitting someone in CLEAR view of another watcher. Nothing. Stealing whilst I'm standing 2m further and Nix drops it off in front of me. HELLO???
Character should be able to be customized.

(i beat this at launch with a month of ubisoft+ and am now back on steam)

outlaws is a fun game, but it has a big problem. it's got fun adventure and stealth and stealing, and your trenchcoat robot friend is neat and should have been more of an active character, and it is SO nice to have a star wars game completely devoid of jedi and light side/dark side nonsense. the problem with this game is one that pervades the entirety of it, and it's how the main character, Kay Starwars-Outlaws, is written as an absolute dope.

to be clear up front: this is NOT about kay's voice actor or appearance or performance, i absolutely hate the creepy chuds online who are mad about "having to" play as a woman - this is about how she is written, the bad material that her actor had to try and make work. i was in fact extremely excited at the idea of being a cool lady smuggler in star wars world, and was very impressed when she meets the rebel alliance early on and simply does not give a heck about them. the problem is everything else - through the mechanics you learn that she's a good marksman and climber, but is otherwise written as a complete idiot with no drive or ambition or charm. for a movie criminal she's a horrible liar and it is Always clear when she's lying, and she constantly swerves on a dime between naive good-hearted helpful main character and weird bumbling greedy idiot. she doesn't even seem to know how the communication of criminal culture works despite growing up on crime world with crime mom, and she would be absolutely incapable of doing the work she's supposed to do without her cute sentient alien dog with the convenient ability to do most of her stealing and button-pressing for her. nyx is great, but it's so clear through the writing and gameplay that he is effectively the only one of the pair who can get things done.

i understand the impulse to make outlaws a story about the origin of an eventually successful smuggler, but Massive swung way too hard in the "inexperienced" direction and made her an oaf who never stops being an oaf. instead of being a cool down-on-her-luck small time criminal with dreams of glory, she's an arrogant screw-up who only survives through luck and wild coincidence. we meet her and are immediately told by every other character that she's a screw-up, despite being taught by her very experienced crime mom, and then she screws up the first two heists you do by either not paying attention or suddenly pointing her gun at her squad and yelling about money. you learn very quickly that kay is a strangely unlikeable protagonist.

the story then just dumps a bunch of convenient resources on her with very little justification - she just Happens to stumble on a big cool spaceship that is equipped with a speeder and a dude's jacket that somehow fits her perfectly, as if it was designed for her, and then just Happens to crash land on top of a guy who wants to help her fix her ship, and she's barely even suspicious when he says he'll do it for the love of the game. even with this huge stroke of luck, she still constantly complains, even to crime bosses and people who will give her jobs, that she actually has to do small stealing to be trusted for big stealing. she's not a loveable awkward person that needs to learn to trust her instincts and her dog buddy, she's portrayed as a constantly confused person who always seems baffled that she managed to make it through these harrowing situations, then thinks "oh yeah, i'm the best, that's why" like she's in denial, like she somehow knows that the player was the one who actually did it.

on and on this goes through the entire game - she's always either weirdly standoffish, completely incapable of reading situations, or confused that criminals don't want to be buddies with her. every time she tries to "play it cool," she stammers and gets herself into trouble. she doesn't even grow into the cool han solo-archetype charming rogue they seem to want her to become, people just seem to purposefully ignore her empty-brain awkward stumbling and assume she's more capable than her communication style implies. Kay is written like, if this was a movie and the player didn't get to guide her through heists and missions, she'd immediately get shot because she'd get spotted in enemy territory immediately and fail to stammer her way out of it. the *entire* game hinges on a huge coincidence that saved her from being killed by a criminal syndicate, and then she continually proves that she as a character perhaps wasn't worth saving. and yet the ending is treated as if she's grown into herself, somehow, which never actually happened.

in terms of representation, this game sucks and only serves to play into the false narrative that women can't be cool. i was *so* excited to play a game as a cool smuggler lady, but instead i had to play as a three stooges smuggler lady - me as moe, the idiot who thinks he's a genius, and nyx as a hyper-competent curly (ND-5 is larry in that he is just kinda there a lot of the time and doesnt really do all that much). if they continue this game as a series, they need to write in enough time between games to where kay is *actually* badass. i want to play a character who thinks her way out of trouble, not one who's about to die when a huge deus ex machina gets her out of it.

now that i think about it, though, if they had truly, *purposefully* leaned into the slapstick nature of kay being an idiot, and effectively made outlaws a a mr. magoo/mr bean/wallace&gromit-type doofus comedy in which she literally stumbles into success with the help of her actually-smart companions, this may have been the best video game story ever written

edit: i just learned that outlaws' writer was the same guy who wrote far cry 4 through 6. it now makes a lot of sense that outlaws is full of *ideas* of interesting characters, without any actual effective character writing. that's a problem that's plagued the far cry series for a decade.

I have played for 8 hours but REAL game play is probably an hour!!. I keep meshing (falling through the map) and the game kicks me out and I have to REPEAT the same mission over and over just to fall through the map yet AGAIN!!!. Utterly FRUSTRATING!!
